metadata.description: Long-term historical average annual returns for major asset classes, used for projections beyond 10-year horizons
data_sources: Ibbotson SBBI (Stocks, Bonds, Bills, and Inflation) 1926-2024
metadata.note: Returns are annualized geometric (compound) averages unless otherwise noted. All returns assume reinvestment of dividends/interest.

10_year.notes: As of end of 2025 - above long-term average

5_year.notes: As of end of 2025 - above long-term average

since_1926.notes: 1928-2024 period. Much of outperformance came from 1940-1969 period when many were illiquid micro-caps

since_1970.notes: More in line with S&P 500 since 1970

since_1926.notes: Estimated based on small-cap premium (~1.5%) and value premium (~0.5%) over large-cap blend. Much of historical data from academic research and DFA data.

dfa_us_small_cap_value.notes: DFA US Small Cap Value since 1993 inception

volatility.notes: Higher volatility than large-cap stocks, but premium compensates for risk over long periods

small_cap_value.notes: Small-cap value has shown premium over small-cap blend historically, though cyclical. Combines small-cap and value factor premiums.

total_us_stock.description: Total US stock market (blend of large-cap and small-cap)

since_1926.notes: Weighted average of large-cap (~9.8%) and small-cap (~11.7%) returns. Represents broad US equity market.

since_1970.notes: More recent period with better data quality

30_year.notes: 30-year average, similar to S&P 500 over this period

10_year.notes: As of end of 2025 - above long-term average

volatility.notes: Slightly lower than small-cap alone due to large-cap component

total_us_stock.notes: Represents the entire US stock market. Includes both large-cap and small-cap stocks in market-cap weighted proportion.

since_1926.notes: Approximate, value premium varies by period

value_stocks.notes: Value premium exists but is cyclical and not guaranteed

since_1900_125_year.notes: UBS Global Investment Returns Yearbook. U.S. stands out with ~5% real appreciation, highest among developed nations

non_us_developed_median.notes: Median real appreciation for non-U.S. developed countries significantly lower than U.S.

since_1970.notes: MSCI EAFE Index data available from 1970. More recent period shows better returns than very long-term average.

since_2000.notes: Global equity investors achieved 3.5% annualized real return since 2000, more modest than 20th century

20_year.notes: More recent period, lower than long-term average

developed_markets.source: UBS Global Investment Returns Yearbook 2025, MSCI EAFE Index

since_1988.notes: MSCI Emerging Markets Index inception. Highly volatile with periods of strong performance (1988-1999) alternating with significant drawdowns

since_2000.notes: More recent period, includes major crises and recoveries

20_year.notes: More recent period, lower than longer-term average

volatility.notes: Significantly higher volatility than developed markets

emerging_markets.notes: Higher return potential but with much higher risk. Includes countries like China, India, Brazil, South Korea, etc.

since_1993.notes: DFA International Small Cap Value since inception. Similar factor premiums as U.S. small-cap value.

volatility.notes: Higher volatility than developed markets large-cap, similar to U.S. small-cap value

international_small_cap_value.notes: Limited long-term data, but DFA and other providers show similar value premium patterns as U.S. markets. Combines international diversification with small-cap and value factors.

total_foreign_stock.description: Total international/foreign stock market (developed + emerging markets blend)

since_1970.notes: Weighted average of developed (~8.5%) and emerging (~9.0%) markets. MSCI ACWI ex-US data available from 1970.

since_2000.notes: More recent period, includes both developed and emerging markets

volatility.notes: Moderate volatility, between developed and emerging markets

total_foreign_stock.notes: Represents total international stock market including both developed and emerging markets. Provides diversification benefits relative to U.S. stocks.

30_year.notes: Approximate, varies significantly by starting yield

volatility.notes: Lower volatility than stocks but still subject to interest rate risk

us_treasury_30_year.notes: Higher duration = higher sensitivity to interest rate changes

since_1976.notes: Index inception. Includes government and corporate bonds

us_aggregate_bonds.notes: Starting yield is primary determinant of long-term bond returns

corporate_bonds_baa.notes: Higher yield than Treasuries but with credit risk

since_1980.notes: Higher returns but with significant credit risk and volatility

since_1997.notes: Real return component plus inflation adjustment

tips.notes: Provides inflation protection, real return typically 1-2%

since_1928.notes: 1928-2024 period. Minimal real return over long term

cash_treasury_bills.notes: Preserves capital but minimal growth after inflation

short_term_treasuries.description: Short-term U.S. Treasury bonds (1-5 year maturity)

since_1973.notes: Bloomberg 1-5 Year Treasury Index data available from 1973. Lower return than intermediate/long-term bonds but with lower interest rate risk.

volatility.notes: Low volatility, minimal interest rate risk

short_term_treasuries.notes: Good balance of yield and stability. Lower duration than intermediate/long-term bonds.

intermediate_term_treasuries.description: Intermediate-term U.S. Treasury bonds (5-10 year maturity)

since_1973.notes: Bloomberg Intermediate Treasury Index. Moderate duration risk.

volatility.notes: Moderate volatility, more sensitive to interest rate changes than short-term

intermediate_term_treasuries.notes: Balance between yield and interest rate risk. Typically 0.5-1% higher return than short-term Treasuries.

since_1980.notes: Bloomberg Municipal Bond Index. Tax-equivalent yield higher for investors in higher tax brackets.

tax_advantage.notes: Tax-equivalent yield calculation: nominal yield / (1 - tax rate). Example: 4.5% / (1 - 0.35) = 6.9% for 35% bracket.

municipal_bonds.notes: Attractive for high-income investors due to tax-free status. Credit risk varies by issuer.

since_1978.notes: December 1978 through March 2016. Outperformed Russell 3000 (11.64%) over this period

20_year_rolling.notes: Consistently outperformed stocks in nearly two-thirds of 20-year periods, especially after March 1989

volatility.notes: Significantly lower volatility than stocks (16.0% and 13.8% respectively)

since_1928.notes: 1928-2024 period. Lower returns than stocks but with different risk profile

residential_real_estate.notes: Includes home price appreciation, not rental income

since_1928.notes: 1928-2025 period. Highly volatile, 'feast or famine' pattern

since_1971.notes: January 1971 to May 2025. Slightly above general commodities

volatility.notes: High volatility, double-digit returns in 3 of past 6 decades

gold.notes: Inflation hedge but no yield. Performance varies dramatically by decade

since_1959.notes: July 1959 through March 2004. Fully-collateralized commodity futures offered same return and Sharpe ratio as equities

since_1971.notes: Slightly below gold over this period

correlation.notes: Provides diversification benefits due to negative correlation with stocks and bonds

since_1980.notes: Modern era with Fed inflation targeting

equity_premium.notes: Historical equity risk premium. Stocks have significantly outperformed bonds over long periods

small_cap_premium.notes: Small-cap premium exists but is cyclical and much of historical outperformance came from 1940-1969 period

value_premium.notes: Value premium exists but is cyclical and not guaranteed. More pronounced in small-cap segment

international_diversification.notes: U.S. has outperformed most developed markets over 125-year period, but international diversification still valuable for risk reduction

real_vs_nominal.notes: Real returns are typically 2-3% lower than nominal returns. Essential to consider inflation for long-term planning

decade_variation.notes: Asset class performance varies dramatically by decade. Stocks delivered double-digit returns in 4 of past 5 decades, but 2000-2009 was difficult. No asset class consistently outperforms.

diversification_lesson.notes: Leaders and laggards change continuously. Large caps have underperformed small caps in some decades while outperforming in others. Diversification across asset classes is essential.

recommended_use.for_20_30_year_projections: Use 30-year historical averages as starting point, adjust for current valuations
recommended_use.for_30_plus_year_projections: Use 50-100 year historical averages, assume mean reversion
caveats: Past performance does not guarantee future results
Consider both nominal and real returns
Account for fees and taxes in actual planning
Sequence of returns risk matters for retirees

years_4_7_balanced.assessment: Conservative assumption, appropriate given Vanguard's subdued outlook

years_11_30_stocks.assessment: Well-aligned with long-term historical averages. Appropriate for 20+ year horizon

comparison_to_retirement_plan.conclusion: Your retirement plan's return assumptions are conservative for years 1-10 (appropriate given current valuations) and align well with long-term historical averages for years 11-30. The 10% assumption for the final 20 years is consistent with 30-100 year S&P 500 historical returns.
